name: Pear rust
summary: Pear rust is a fungal disease that primarily affects pear trees, causing bright orange spots on leaves and can also damage fruit. It involves a complex lifecycle often requiring juniper as an alternate host.

cause_of_disease.describe: Pear rust is caused by a fungus that requires both pear and juniper trees to complete its lifecycle.
The fungus overwinters on juniper trees and releases spores that infect pear trees in the spring.
High humidity and wet conditions promote the spread and infection of the fungus.

steps: Carefully inspect the pear tree for infected leaves.
Prune and dispose of infected leaves to prevent the spread of the fungus.
Select an appropriate fungicide recommended for pear rust.
Apply fungicide according to the manufacturer's instructions during early spring when spores are active.

solution.solution: Remove juniper trees in the vicinity
steps: Identify any juniper trees within a few hundred meters of the pear tree.
Consider removing those juniper trees to break the lifecycle of the fungus.

tips: Regularly monitor both pear and juniper trees for early signs of rust infection.
Maintain good air circulation around the pear tree by proper pruning.
Ensure the pear tree has a proper nutrient balance to improve its resistance to diseases.
